Award.AwardTitle: RCN - SEES: Sustainable Cities - People and the Energy-Climate-Water Nexus

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1140384 (Ramaswami). This award is funded under NSF's Science, Engineering, and Education for Sustainability (SEES) activities, which aims to address the challenges of creating a sustainable world. This project will develop a research collaboration network (RCN) across 20+ US universities and 2 national labs to coordinate work on the overarching theme of sustainable cities, with focus on reducing energy use, carbon emissions and mitigating climate-risks to water supply and public health in cities. The US network will collaborate with international sustainability research networks (in Australia, EU, Asia) and with a network of practitioners and policymakers in US and global cities. RCN activities will lead to the development of (a) inter-disciplinary systems framework(s) to represent linkages between people, infrastructures and the natural system, from the city-scale to the global scale, that shape sustainability outcomes in cities, (b) harmonized methods and international data standards to operationalize the framework, to report, for example, the carbon footprints of cities, water vulnerability of cities, or to analyze social actors who shape urban infrastructures and consumption patterns toward sustainability, (c) a network of 12 global cities for testing the framework and its component theories and models/methods in cities with different natural, infrastructural, socioeconomic and cultural characteristics, (d) a virtual collaborative forum to share research methods, experiences and teaching tools across more than 20+ US universities on the common thematic area of sustainable cities. The RCN will provide science based systems analysis tools, much needed by more than 1000 cities worldwide that are developing sustainability plans addressing energy, water and climate change. A unique aspect of this RCN is broad-based integration across urban ecology, industrial ecology, atmospheric sciences, infrastructure engineering, architecture, urban planning, behavioral sciences, public affairs and public health toward the goal of sustainable cities. Cross-discipline integration, coordination of data across scales, and cross-city comparisons are expected to advance the science of sustainable cities. The RCN has potential to impact more than 1200 students in participating US universities and 65 million people in the network of cities where field work will be coordinated. Dissemination potential is high through network links with policy groups such as ICLEI-USA and The World Bank who work with cities worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals of our RCN included:

  1. Share experiences implementing an interdisciplinary systems framework related to sustainable infrastructure and cities by:
    1. Creating a virtual collaborative forum
    2. Distributing an E-Newsletter connecting researchers with policymakers and professionals
    3. Developing products such as review papers, policy papers, and synthesis papers
    4. Reporting on harmonized methods and data standards
    5. Sharing key research insights and best practices for interdisciplinary education on sustainable cities through in-person and on-line workshops.
    6. Develop a network of researchers who are aware of each other’s work and have formed partnerships to develop new grants
    7. Create opportunities for students to network and discuss their research and professional opportunities

These goals were accomplished, which led to the following outcomes.

 

Outcomes

1a) Creating a virtual collaborative forum

The following virtual collaborative forums were created:

  • Website: http://www.rcnsustainablecities.com/
  • Blog: https://sustainablecitiesrcn.wordpress.com/
  • LinkedIn: RCN Sustainable Cities
  • Twitter: https://twitter.com/RCNcities

At the completion of this grant the blog had over 276 followers and a total of 2,217 file downloads. The RCN LinkedIn group had 89 members including graduate students, faculty, and city officials. The RCN Twitter account had a total of 64 followers and had been used for 112 tweets.

 

1b) Distribute an E-Newsletter connecting researchers with policymakers and professionals

An E-newsletter was sent bi-monthly through the RCN and had 235 subscribers by the end of 2017. The RCN Newsletter has since been expanded to include the SRN Sustainable Healthy Cities Network, and is now called the RCN-SRN Newsletter.

 

1c) Developing products such as review papers, policy papers, and synthesis papers

Eight publications were produced through this RCN, including “Translating Research to Policy for Sustainable Cities,” published in the Journal of Industrial Ecology, and “Capturing Structural and Functional Diversity through Institutional Analysis: The Mayor Position in City Charters” published in Urban Affairs Review.  In addition, commentaries on UN-Habitat issue papers were published, and RCN members Clint Andrews and Anu Ramaswami were quoted in a New York Times article which focused on metrics to compare sustainability of cities.

In August 2017, RCN-SRN researchers met to plan for a journal special issue on interdisciplinary perspectives on distributed infrastructure. The outcome of this workshop will be a publication submitted in 2018.

 

1d) Reporting on harmonized methods and data standards

The first RCN supported workshop hosted in 2012 led to the development of the U.S. Community Protocol for Accounting and Reporting of Greenhouse Gas Emissions, a collaborative effort between the RCN and the International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives (ICLEI). The Community Protocol is a detailed document published by ICLEI with new methodologies and best practices to help local governments measure and report their emissions.

 

1e) Sharing key research insights and best practices for interdisciplinary education on sustainable cities through in-person and on-line workshops.

Sixteen interdisciplinary workshops with over 300 attendees combined were hosted through the RCN. Videos, PowerPoints, and call recordings were shared online after each webinar and workshop. Participants in these workshops included RCN researchers, international scholars, graduate students, tribal leaders, cities, utilities, as well as other public and private partners. Attendees came together to discuss topics ranging from the latest in distributed infrastructure research to pathways for tribal college students to attend 4-year degree Universities.

Outcomes of these activities included the sharing of best practices for interdisciplinary education on sustainable cities; identification of collaborative research projects; graduate students obtaining a deeper understanding of interdisciplinary research; and multi-sectoral approaches for developing solutions to urban challenges.

 

2) Develop a network of researchers who are aware of each other’s work and have formed partnerships to develop new grants

Valuable partnerships were developed through the collaborative forums, e-newsletter, and workshops, which helped U.S. and international researchers come together to share their research. These partnerships have resulted in multiple grant proposals, two of which were awarded by NSF. The first was the SRN Sustainable Healthy Cities grant awarded on August 1, 2015. The second NSF grant awarded was a Smart and Connected Communities grant, awarded in late 2017. RCN-SRN affiliates also responded to a call by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering for community input on international network-to-network collaboration; they proposed the development of a Sustainable Urban Systems Science-to-Action International Network.

In 2018 SRN-RCN researchers have plans to develop a website to connect researchers with Social-Environmental-Infrastructure-Urban Form datasets for varying scales and regions. The website will be used to catalogue datasets and models used in sustainable infrastructure studies, including those developed through RCN partnerships.  

 

3) Create opportunities for students to network and discuss their research and professional opportunities

Graduate students and post-docs participated in all of the workshops hosted through the RCN. Many presented their research findings at the workshops as well and took advantage of opportunities to network with city, state, utility and other public and private representatives. Three of the workshops were designed specifically with student training and professional development in mind.
